3727416535.given_title: Chinese Tech Terms Explained In English | 16x Engineer
3727416535.resolved_title: Chinese Tech Terms Explained In English
3727416535.excerpt: Chinese tech companies like ByteDance and Tencent are setting up engineering offices outside China. Local hires in these global offices are becoming a norm. These locally hired engineers typically have limited Chinese language proficiency.

3495985697.given_title: China’s Digital Landscape in 2020 | KAWO 科握
3495985697.excerpt: As we begin to emerge from the chaos, 75% of Chinese consumers are optimistic that the economy will start to recover in the next 6 months. We’ve also seen how digital channels are more important than ever to reach consumers.

4005140226.given_title: The Triumph and Terror of Wang Huning
4005140226.resolved_title: The Triumph and Terror of Wang Huning
4005140226.excerpt: One day in August 2021, Zhao Wei disappeared. For one of China’s best-known actresses to physically vanish from public view would have been enough to cause a stir on its own. But Zhao’s disappearing act was far more thorough: overnight, she was erased from the internet.

3827321030.given_title: Chinese chipmaking technology development may stall at 40nm scale - DIGITIM

3803927537.resolved_title: 9 viral phrases that explain China’s work culture
3803927537.excerpt: In China, the culture of work has changed radically over the years. Alongside those changes came a whole array of viral phrases, forever immortalized in the lexicon of the Chinese workplace.

3944060423.given_title: Why thousands of young Chinese people use a pink dinosaur as their alias
3944060423.resolved_title: Why thousands of young Chinese people use a pink dinosaur as their alias
3944060423.excerpt: Emily Yuan, a high school student in Guizhou, lives a double life on the Chinese internet. On her main social media accounts on WeChat and Weibo, Yuan shares photos of herself and posts about school events, like a recent debate competition, for her friends and family to see.

4010478195.given_title: Want to stop livestreaming? That’ll be $42,000
4010478195.resolved_title: Want to stop livestreaming? That’ll be $42,000
4010478195.excerpt: Calligraphy teacher Liu Fengyang thought he was kick-starting his career in entertainment when a livestreaming talent agency reached out to him in mid-2023.

3878746597.resolved_title: Real estate is China's economic Achilles heel
3878746597.excerpt: This is the second in a short series of posts about China’s economy. The first post, from last week, was entitled “Where China is beating the world”.

3728966316.given_title: Biden Just Clobbered China’s Chip Industry
3728966316.resolved_title: Biden Just Clobbered China’s Chip Industry
3728966316.excerpt: Semiconductors are among the most intricate tools that human beings have ever invented. They are also among the most expensive to make. The latest chips — the sort that power supercomputers and high-end smartphones — are densely packed with transistors so small they’re measured in nanometers.

3820648913.given_title: The Daring Ruse That Exposed China’s Campaign to Steal American Secrets
3820648913.resolved_title: The Daring Ruse That Exposed China’s Campaign to Steal American Secrets
3820648913.excerpt: Open this article in the New York Times Audio app on iOS. In March 2017, an engineer at G.E. Aviation in Cincinnati whom I will refer to using part of his Chinese given name — Hua — received a request on LinkedIn.

3876108648.given_title: The Mystery of the Disappearing van Gogh
3876108648.resolved_title: The Mystery of the Disappearing van Gogh
3876108648.excerpt: After a painting by the Dutch artist sold at auction, a movie producer claimed to be the owner. It later vanished from sight, with a trail leading to Caribbean tax havens and a jailed Chinese billionaire. The bidding for Lot 17 started at $23 million.

4007951825.given_title: China’s Investors Are Losing Faith in Its Markets and Economy
4007951825.resolved_title: What a Viral Post on Giraffes Says About China’s Fed-Up Investors
4007951825.excerpt: Like many Chinese people, Jacky hoped that he could make enough money investing in China’s stock markets to help pay for an apartment in a big city. But in 2015 he lost $30,000, and in 2021 he lost $80,000.

4008938823.given_title: ‘Shawshank’ in China, as You’ve Never Seen It Before
4008938823.resolved_title: ‘Shawshank’ in China, as You’ve Never Seen It Before
4008938823.excerpt: When a stage production of “The Shawshank Redemption” opened recently in China, it was cast entirely with Western actors speaking fluent Mandarin Chinese. But that may have been the least surprising part of the show.

3828384964.resolved_title: Tech war: China’s flagship CPU designer Loongson puts on a brave face amid US sanctions
3828384964.excerpt: Loongson Technology Corp, whose founder Hu Weiwu used to cite Mao Zedong to express his aspirations, is evaluating the advanced 7-nanometre process from a number of foundries to manufacture its future chips, according to a response from the company this week to investor questions.

1.caption: Loongson is China’s home-grown designer of central processing units, reducing the country’s reliance on Intel and AMD. Photo: Shutterstock

3791702829.given_title: Spirited Away: A Peek into the World of China’s Door Gods
3791702829.resolved_title: Spirited Away: A Peek into the World of China’s Door Gods
3791702829.excerpt: Every Lunar New Year, they are always outside the door: Portraits of two heavily armed and fierce warriors donned in colorful battle armor.

5.caption: The double Guan Yu door gods, produced in Wuqiang County, Hebei province.

6.caption: The single Guan Yu door god, produced in Wuqiang County, Hebei province. A rare print of a door god from the front.

9.caption: Generic warriors produced in Mianzhu, Sichuan province.

10.caption: A Taohuawu woodblock New Year print shows officials surrounded by five young boys each, produced in Suzhou, Jiangsu province.

11.caption: Door gods dressed as the top students in the old imperial exams, produced in Nantong, Jiangsu province.

3901218595.given_title: The ‘Old Dough Sticks’: Life Among Beijing’s Least Eligible Bachelors
3901218595.resolved_title: The ‘Old Dough Sticks’: Life Among Beijing’s Least Eligible Bachelors
3901218595.excerpt: It was a Saturday afternoon in September, and Wang Lei was looking for love. The 37-year-old unmarried marketing agent from a northern Chinese province was headed to one of his favorite haunts: an unassuming residential compound in southeastern Beijing that hosts a weekly matchmaking party.

3923949139.given_title: The fascinating evolution of typing Chinese characters
3923949139.resolved_title: The fascinating evolution of typing Chinese characters
3923949139.excerpt: This story first appeared in China Report, MIT Technology Review’s newsletter about technology developments in China. Sign up to receive it in your inbox every Tuesday.

2.caption: The diagram above shows how each key is matched with three to 12 character components. The texts at bottom are poems to help users remember the combinations.

3.caption: A guide on how the character 犬 should be typed into Wubi software.

3840287000.given_title: China’s Massive Fleet Of Radar Planes And The Strategy Behind It
3840287000.resolved_title: China’s Massive Fleet Of Radar Planes And The Strategy Behind It
3840287000.excerpt: While the rapid pace of developments across China’s military aerospace domain has been widely reported, the focus has typically been weighted toward fighter jets and, to a lesser extent, bombers.

1.caption: A Nanchang Q-5 Fantan attack jet prepares for takeoff in a scene typical of the PLAAF in the mid -980s, when outdated aircraft types and sheer weight of numbers were the order of the day. Sovfoto/Universal Images Group via Getty Images

2.caption: The most recognizable AEW&C platform is the American E-3 Sentry AWACS which serves multiple allies including NATO but is now rapidly aging and becoming hard to support. NATO

3.caption: A PLAAF KJ-500 arrives at Zhuhai to take part in the Airshow China exhibition. FengJian Aviation Photos/via Chinese internet

4.caption: A KJ-500 AEW&C aircraft is visible on the taxiway in this view of Fiery Cross Reef, which has become a heavily militarized manmade island, complete with airfield and accompanying hangars. Photo by Ezra Acayan/Getty Images Getty Images

5.caption: A preserved prototype KJ-1, based on a Soviet-made Tu-4 bomber re-engined with turboprops. Flavio Mucia/Wikimedia Commons

6.caption: A model of the AEW&C version of the Y-10 civil airliner. DZ Scan/via Chinese internet

7.caption: A Nimrod AEW3, one of a small batch of Nimrod aircraft converted to this configuration before the program was abandoned in favor of the U.S-built E-3 Sentry AWACS. Mike Freer/Wikimedia Commons

8.caption: After its return from Israel, the former A-50I prototype became the prototype for the KJ-2000 and received this China Flight Test Establishment color scheme. Longshi/via Chinese internet

9.caption: An apparently official PLAAF photo of a KJ-2000, serial number 30571, assigned to the 26th Division. Top81/via Chinese internet

10.caption: A side view of a standard PLAAF KJ-2000, albeit with the serial number censored from the photo. FYJS/via Chinese internet

11.caption: China’s inability to procure more Il-76 airframes for conversion to KJ-2000s has provided added impetus to other AEW&C programs, namely the KJ-200 and KJ-500. Longshi/via Chinese internet

12.caption: Now used as an engine testbed, the prototype KJ-2000 is seen its maiden flight with the WS-18 turbofan in October 2014. Chinese Military Aviation/via Chinese internet

13.caption: An inflight photo of the Y-8J reveals the characteristic drooped nose radome. Longshi/via Chinese internet

14.caption: A recent photo of a PLAN Naval Aviation Y-8J, with its new low-visibility markings. via Chinese internet

15.caption: The Y-8F‑200 after being converted into a radar testbed for the ‘Balance Beam’ configuration. Top81/via Chinese internet

16.caption: A KJ-200A operated by the 26th Division, PLAAF. B747SPNKG/via Chinese internet

17.caption: A KJ-200A displays the revised nose configuration with a new and larger radome. China Aviation Photography/via Chinese internet

18.caption: A Naval Aviation KJ-200H. As evidenced by the ‘Pinocchio’ nose, these aircraft are not yet modified to KJ-200A standard. China Military/via Chinese internet

19.caption: The latest KJ-200B version. Q30/via Chinese internet

20.caption: A poor quality but rare photo apparently showing a KJ-200B in operational service. via Chinese internet

21.caption: A KJ-200A fitted with an inflight refueling probe above the cockpit is unofficially known as the KJ-200AG. Note also the ESM antennas on the rear fuselage. Longshi/via Chinese internet

22.caption: The Y-8 AEW&C rotodome testbed, serial number T0518, which appeared in early 2006. BWRY Photos/via Chinese internet

23.caption: A Pakistan Air Force ZDK-03 flies over Islamabad during rehearsals for the Pakistan Day parade in Islamabad on March 13, 2017. FAROOQ NAEEM/AFP via Getty Images

24.caption: A standard PLAAF KJ-500. China Aviation Photography/via Chinese internet

25.caption: Another view of the same KJ-500. via Chinese internet

26.caption: The probe-equipped KJ-500A is the current production variant. via Chinese internet

27.caption: While PLAN KJ-500Hs are now adopting low-visibility markings, this example sports a much more flamboyant scheme. via Chinese internet

28.caption: PLAN Ka-31s operational with the Eastern Theater Command. via Chinese internet

29.caption: A Ka-31 during trials onboard the amphibious assault ship Guangxi. Chinese Military Aviation/via Chinese internet

30.caption: One of the first clear photos of the improved Z-18YJ. via Chinese internet

31.caption: A Z-18J with its radar deployed, while being intercepted by the Japanese military. Japan Self-Defense Forces

32.caption: A satellite image of one of the first KJ-600s. via Chinese internet

33.caption: Another satellite image shows a KJ-600 prototype in the green primer paint now frequently seen on Chinese naval aircraft. via Chinese internet

34.caption: One of the first clear photos showing the forward fuselage of the KJ-600. via Chinese internet

4001730909.given_title: FBI confirms it issued remote kill command to blow out Volt Typhoon's botne
4001730909.resolved_title: FBI confirms it issued remote kill command to blow out Volt Typhoon's botnet
4001730909.excerpt: China's Volt Typhoon attackers used "hundreds" of outdated Cisco and NetGear routers infected with malware in an attempt to break into US critical infrastructure facilities, according to the Justice Department.
